<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/53  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 338, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 445, 91]]<|/det|>
1 For a set of 40 values of \(x\), it is found that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 102, 677, 122]]<|/det|>
\[
\sum(x-k)=836.0, \quad \sum(x-k)^{2}=25410.8,
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 289, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 168, 144, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 166, 682, 184]]<|/det|>
(a) Given that the mean of these 40 values is 124.0 , find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 446, 144, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 555, 462]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the standard deviation of these 40 values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
2 At a large college, all students who study Science also study exactly one of Art or Drama or Music. \(20 \%\) of these students study Art, \(45 \%\) study Drama and \(35 \%\) study Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 710, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) 3 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 677, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that at least 1 of these students studies Drama.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 460, 720, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) 10 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 490, 601, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that more than 7 study Art or Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
3 A fair six-sided dice with faces labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is thrown repeatedly until a 3 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 278, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\mathrm{P}(X=8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 306, 144, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 306, 280, 323]]<|/det|>
(b) Find \(\mathrm{P}(X<9)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 553, 144, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 552, 784, 570]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that a 3 is obtained for the second time before the 6th throw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
4 84 people attempt a particular puzzle. The times taken, in minutes, to complete the puzzle are recorded. These times are represented in the cumulative frequency graph below.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 131, 824, 520]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 555, 144, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 555, 918, 587]]<|/det|>
(a) Use the graph to estimate how many people took between 4 and 7.5 minutes to complete the puzzle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) On the grid below, draw a box-and-whisker plot to summarise the information in the cumulative frequency graph.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 114, 789, 325]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 631, 91]]<|/det|>
5 Bag \(A\) contains 6 red marbles, 5 blue marbles and 1 green marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 507, 122]]<|/det|>
Bag \(B\) contains 5 red marbles and 3 blue marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 606, 153]]<|/det|>
A marble is chosen at random from bag \(A\) and placed in bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 167, 488, 183]]<|/det|>
A marble is now chosen at random from bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 199, 144, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 198, 846, 215]]<|/det|>
(a) Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, giving the probability on each branch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 670, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that both marbles chosen are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 445, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that the marble chosen from bag \(A\) is blue, given that the marble chosen from bag \(B\) is blue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
6 A company sells bags of pasta. The masses of large bags of pasta are normally distributed with mean 2.50 kg and standard deviation 0.12 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that the mass of pasta in a randomly chosen large bag is less than 2.65 kg . 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 418, 581, 435]]<|/det|>
<pre>A restaurant manager buys 160 of these large bags of pasta.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 450, 144, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 450, 918, 482]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the number of bags for which you would expect the mass of pasta to be more than 1.65 standard deviations above the mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<pre>The masses of small bags of pasta sold by the company are normally distributed with mean \(\mu \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). Tests show that \(77 \%\) of these bags have masses greater than 1.26 kg , and \(44 \%\) have masses less than 1.35 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 138, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 136, 584, 154]]<|/det|>
(c) Find, in either order, the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 902, 91]]<|/det|>
7 A set of friends consists of 7 men and 4 women. Three of the men are brothers: Ali, Ben and Charlie.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 106, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men in a line in which Ali and Ben do not stand next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 460, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men and 4 women in a line in which all the men stand together and all the women stand together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) In how many ways can the 7 men and 4 women be divided into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 if there are no restrictions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 429, 144, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 428, 900, 445]]<|/det|>
(d) The 7 men and 4 women are divided at random into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 459, 712, 476]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Ali, Ben and Charlie are all in the same group.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
